Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CRISP Type 2: Revolution through Evolution: A Controls Approach to Improve How Society Interacts with Electricity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CRISP project addresses the challenges associated with the rapid evolution of the electricity grid to a highly distributed infrastructure. The keystone of this research is the transformation of power distribution feeders, from relatively passive channels for delivering electricity to customers, to distribution microgrids, entities that actively manage local production, storage and use of electricity, with participation from individual customers. Distribution microgrids combine the advantages of the traditional electricity grid with the advantages of emerging distributed technologies, including the ability to produce and use power locally in the event of grid outages. The project will result in a unified model that incorporates key aspects of power generation and delivery, information flow, market design and human behavior. The model predictions can be used by policymakers to guide a transition to clean energy via distribution microgrids. The expectation is to enable at least 50% of electric power to come from renewable resources. This cannot be done with either the traditional grid, due to its limited capacity to accommodate intermittent renewable power sources, or with fully decentralized approaches, which would not be affordable for most utility customers.

This project addresses many socio-technological gaps necessary to translate from research discovery to commercial applications. To date, there is no theoretical framework to ensure system stability as renewable energy routed through power electronics replaces traditional rotating machinery. To achieve an optimal mix of storage performance and information bandwidth and to design nonlinear controllers, we will use Hamiltonian Surface Shaping Power Flow Control theory. We will study methods to detect malicious tampering with information flows. The complex interaction of intermittent resources, human behavior and market structures will be modeled in an agent-based simulation. System inputs will be provided by utility and meteorological data, and by behavioral models that incorporate information obtained by surveys, interviews and metering data. Emergent system dynamics will be abstracted and studied using dynamical complex network theory, to explore stability limits as a function of human behavior and market design. Finally, the effect of enhanced controllability of distribution systems on the robustness of large energy-information-social networks will be analyzed using interdependent Markov-chain models. Graduate students involved in this program will be exposed to a unique combination of skills from engineering, data analysis and social sciences; such cross-disciplinary training will prepare them for leadership roles in the emerging energy economy of tomorrow.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CRISP project has addressed the challenges associated with the rapid evolution of the electricity grid, from one with a few large centralized generators providing power to millions of users to a transactive grid with numerous distributed energy resources. These resources (e.g. rooftop photovoltaic systems, electric cars, smart thermostats or ventilation systems) play a vital role managing energy flows. The keystone of this research is the transformation of power distribution feeders, from relatively passive channels that deliver electricity from the transmission grid to acquiescent customers, to distribution microgrids, which are highly intelligent entities that actively manage production, storage and use of electricity, where individuals are active participants. Distribution microgrids make it possible to combine the advantages of the traditional electricity grid, including the ability to transfer renewable energy across wide geographical areas, with the advantages of emerging technologies, including the ability to produce and use power locally in the event of major grid outages. The project has studied how the telecommunications infrastructure delivers information to human and artificial stakeholders to enable rational and optimal decision-making on various aspects of energy utilization. Critically, this research has considered the interface between human energy users and the myriad systems that manage the flows of energy, from smart thermostats to utility control rooms. The project has resulted in a unified model that incorporates key aspects of power generation and delivery, market design and human behavior. The model predictions can be used by policymakers to guide a transition to clean energy via distribution microgrids. Distribution microgrids are expected to enable at least 50% of electric power to come from renewable resources. This cannot be done with the traditional grid, due to its limited capacity to accommodate the intermittency of renewable power sources, nor can it be done with fully decentralized approaches, which would not be affordable for most utility customers due to the high cost of storage devices.

This project has addressed many socio-technological gaps necessary to translate from research discovery to commercial applications. First, as traditional generation involving large rotating masses (i.e. inertial) is replaced by renewable generation routed through power electronics devices, there is the strong possibility of losing system stability. To date, there is no theoretical framework to ensure system stability without this inertia. This gap has been filled by the Hamiltonian Surface Shaping Power Flow Control theory, which has been used to achieve an optimal mix of storage performance and information bandwidth and to design nonlinear controllers. System inputs have been provided by utility and meteorological data, and by models of human behavior that incorporate information obtained by surveys, interviews and measurements from advanced metering infrastructure in one or more communities. Large data sets have also been used to study methods to detect malicious tampering with information flows. High-fidelity representations of power flow in the distribution infrastructure, resulting from the complex interaction of intermittent resources, human behavior and market structures, have been implemented in an agent-based simulation model. System dynamics that emerge from the agent-based model have been abstracted and studied using dynamical complex network theory, to explore stability limits as a function of human behavior and market design. Finally, the effect of enhanced controllability of distribution systems on the robustness and stability of the large energy-information-social network has been analyzed using interdependent Markov-chain models.

We have also studied the problem of optimally protecting a power network under attack. We have investigated the role of the network topology, as well as of the distribution of attackers and defenders over the network.  An additional impact has regarded a mathematical analysis of the swing equation based on a modal decomposition, which allows to predict how perturbations propagate over a complex heterogeneous network that is meant to model a smart grid. 

The project has engaged universities and research centers across the nation. The experience of the University of New Mexico in designing distributed energy systems has been complemented by Fraunhofer’s unique insight in human-technology interfaces and University of Tennessee’s strengths in studying the social-psychological factors affecting demand response behaviors. Michigan Tech's strength in both control theory and data analysis has provided the non-human decision-making components. The University of New Mexico and Texas Tech University have studied how distribution system behavior affects the robustness of the transmission grid. The outcome of the combination of these research thrusts is twofold: (1) a unique tool to explore the performance and dynamics of the complex interactive infrastructures underlying future smart grids, and (2) a theoretical basis for their fundamental understanding.

Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows involved in this program have been exposed to a unique combination of skills from engineering, data analysis and social sciences; such cross-disciplinary training will prepare them for leadership roles in the emerging energy economy of tomorrow. A total of five Ph.D. students supported by this grant have graduated.
